There are several ways to start a career in ML since it all depends on where you are right now: Are you a CS undergrad student just about to graduate? Do you have a PhD in some science (e.g. Math, or Physics)? Have you been working as a software engineer or analyst for years? Where you are right now will determine what is your best path forward. Let me address a couple of those possibilities: (1) You are a Software Engineer with some years of experience In this case, I would recommend you take the following steps: Learn some basics of ML (see My answer to Machine Learning: How do I learn machine Continue Reading There are several ways to start a career in ML since it all depends on where you are right now: Are you a CS undergrad student just about to graduate? Do you have a PhD in some science (e.g. Math, or Physics)? Have you been working as a software engineer or analyst for years? Where you are right now will determine what is your best path forward. Let me address a couple of those possibilities: (1) You are a Software Engineer with some years of experience In this case, I would recommend you take the following steps: Learn some basics of ML (see My answer to Machine Learning: How do I learn machine learning? ) Find a job or position in a team that does ML, but where your role is mostly to support software engineering (This should be relatively easy to do if you are a great software engineer and you show your interest in ML by having done (1)). Continue learning “on the job” and don't miss any opportunity to get more and more involved in the details of the ML algorithms you/your team is working on Progressively move into doing more ML until it becomes your “full-time” job (2) You are an CS undergrad about to graduate You could start a career as a software engineer and then go into (1) or... You could decide to do some graduate work (Master or PhD) in ML to get you jump started (3) You are a “science” PhD or researcher I am assuming you have used ML and become somewhat proficient at applying it for studying data and phenomena. Otherwise, you should learn the basics of ML (see My answer to Machine Learning: How do I learn machine learning? ) Improve your coding. You might have used some R (or worse, Matlab). I would recommend you do yourself a favor and learn Python. There are many places now that specialize on training people with this kind of background through Data Science boot camps and the like (see Zipfianacademy for example). I don't know enough about these to recommend them, but it might be a good way to improve 1 and 2. There are even universities that have courses in teaching coding/software engineering to Data Scientists (see this course at UW, for example). Get a job as a Data Scientist and progressively move into doing more and more ML Of course, there are infinite variations of the three situations above, and I don't claim these simple pieces of advice are enough. But, I do hope they can help you out if you are in a roughly similar place.

I don’t qualify myself as having a career in machine learning as I don’t spend the majority of my time researching algorithms on a theoretical level. I do, however, have a career that involves machine learning in practice, and I’ll describe that for you. As a Data Scientist, I would describe my career as: Fun - Solving problems are just plain fun. I like to think of a data science problem like a Nintendo game: Some parts can be very frustrating and make you want to quit, but if you power through it, you get to enjoy the fun of beating the game. Interesting - Following how a problem is solved from start to finish is very appealing to those interested in STEM fields. The feeling is comparable to eating your favorite chips, once you get one piece of information, you have to have more until you have to tell yourself to stop. And then have another anyway. Exciting - In data science and machine learning in particular, new approaches are being introduced almost every day. This makes you realize how incredible it is to be a part of an era where technology is making advances we couldn’t have fathomed even 10 years ago. This thrill can make you feel as if you are a part of an elite group that has been appointed to change the world. You might not contribute a whole lot, but you know you’re included. Confusing - When researching a topic, it’s more often than not where you come across something that just won’t stick the first time around. While some concepts might take minutes for others to understand, you might scratch your head for two full days before it truly sinks in. But when it does.. You realize why it was worth it. It’s like being young, having a crush send you mixed signals, and then one day they finally tell you they like you. Different - A career in this field can sometimes make you wonder how 9–5 jobs even exist. You think to yourself I’ve spent 4 weeks on this problem and it doesn’t feel like I’ve made any progress. And then you compare it to a summer job you had when you were younger and recall that most jobs have an immediate turn around on value. They work to provide a service. Now I’m working to generate a solution and there is absolutely no standard on how long it might take. I would say that if any of this sounds intriguing to you then you should hop on the train. Like I said, you don’t have to contribute a whole lot, but simply being a part of it all makes it worth your time. I hope you found this helpful.

MACHINE LEARNING IN THE FEILD OF DATA SCIENCE Machine learning is an important component of data science, the study of how to extract insights from data. Data science requires a diverse set of abilities, ranging from data cleaning and preprocessing to data visualization and machine learning. Machine learning is very significant in data science because it allows us to create prediction models that may be used to make data-driven choices. Machine learning algorithms may forecast which consumers are most likely to purchase a product, which patients are most likely to acquire an illness, or which stocks are likely to do well in the future . Machine learning is also important for the field of artificial intelligence, which is the study of how intelligent computers might be created. Machine learning is used to educate robots to execute activities that would otherwise need human intellect, such as object recognition in photos, natural language interpretation, and game play . Machine learning is also used in robotics to allow robots to learn from their surroundings and adapt to new conditions. TOP CAREER PATHS IN MACHINE LEARNING DATA SCIENTIST A data scientist is someone with expertise in extracting insights from data. They examine data using a range of approaches, including machine learning, to identify patterns and trends . Data scientists work in a variety of areas, including healthcare, banking, retail, and e-commerce . They might be working on tasks like anticipating customer turnover, improving marketing strategies, or creating new products . A degree in an area such as computer science, mathematics, or statistics is often required to become a data scientist. You should also have good programming abilities and be familiar with technologies like Python, R, and SQL . Furthermore, you must grasp machine learning methods and be able to apply them to real-world issues. MACHINE LEARNING ENGINEER A machine learning engineer is someone who specializes in building and deploying machine learning models. They work on the entire machine learning pipeline, from data preprocessing to model training and deployment . Machine learning engineers work closely with data scientists to turn their models into production-ready systems. They may work on projects such as building recommendation systems, developing fraud detection algorithms, or automating customer service . To become a machine learning engineer, you typically need a degree in computer science or a related field . You also need to have strong programming skills and be proficient in machine learning tools such as TensorFlow. DEEP LEARNING ENGINEER A deep learning engineer is someone who specializes in building and deploying deep learning models. Deep learning is a subset of machine learning that involves training models with multiple layers of artificial neural networks. Deep learning engineers work on projects such as image and speech recognition, natural language processing, and autonomous vehicles . To become a deep learning engineer, you typically need a degree in computer science or a related field. DATA ANALYST A data analyst is someone who specializes in analyzing data to uncover insights and trends . They use a variety of statistical and machine learning techniques to analyze data and present their findings to stakeholders. Data analysts work in a wide range of industries, from healthcare and finance to retail and e-commerce . To become a data analyst, you typically need a degree in a field such as mathematics, statistics, or economics . You also need to have strong programming skills and be proficient in tools such as Python or R . In addition, you need to have a good understanding of statistical methods and be able to apply them to real-world problems. CONCLUSION Machine learning is a fascinating and fast expanding field with several job options. Whether you enjoy data science, artificial intelligence, or research, there is a machine learning profession for you. To get started in machine learning, you must have a solid foundation in mathematics and computer science, as well as programming and machine learning tool knowledge . You should also be able to think critically and apply your knowledge to real-world challenges. As the demand for machine learning experts continues to rise, there are many exciting career paths for individuals interested in this field. Machine Learning Engineer: This role involves designing, developing, and implementing machine learning models. Machine learning engineers are responsible for creating algorithms and models that can be used in real-world applications. They work with data scientists, software engineers, and other stakeholders to ensure that the models are accurate and scalable. Data Scientist : Data scientists are responsible for using machine learning algorithms to analyze and make predictions from data. They work with large data sets and use statistical methods to build models and make insights. Data scientists need to have a strong background in both statistics and programming, as well as the ability to communicate complex findings to non-technical stakeholders. Artificial Intelligence Engineer: Artificial intelligence engineers are responsible for designing and developing AI systems and algorithms. They work with machine learning models and other AI technologies to build intelligent systems that can process and analyze vast amounts of data. Artificial intelligence engineers also collaborate with data scientists and machine learning engineers to ensure that their AI systems are accurate and scalable. Research Scientist: Research scientists in the field of machine learning are responsible for exploring new algorithms, models, and technologies in this field. They conduct research and experiments to advance the state-of-the-art in machine learning and often publish their findings in academic journals. Research scientists are also involved in developing new applications for machine learning, such as healthcare and financial services. Business Intelligence Analyst: Business intelligence analysts use machine learning algorithms to analyze large data sets and extract insights that can inform business decisions. They work with stakeholders across the organization to identify opportunities for growth and optimization. Business intelligence analysts must have strong analytical skills and the ability to communicate complex data insights to stakeholders. Deep Learning Engineer: Deep learning is a specialized subfield of machine learning that involves training neural networks to perform complex tasks, such as image recognition, natural language processing, and autonomous navigation. Deep learning engineers are responsible for designing and developing deep learning models, and ensuring that these models are accurate and scalable. Autonomous Systems Engineer: Autonomous systems engineers are responsible for designing and developing systems that can operate without human intervention. They work with machine learning algorithms to build intelligent systems that can process data, make predictions, and take actions. Autonomous systems engineers must have a strong understanding of robotics, control systems, and machine learning. In conclusion, there are numerous exciting career paths for individuals interested in machine learning. Whether you're interested in research, engineering, or business intelligence, there is a role for you in this rapidly growing field. To succeed in a career in machine learning, you'll need to have a strong foundation in statistics, programming, and data analysis, as well as the ability to think creatively and solve complex problems.

R [3] is great for statistics and plo Continue Reading In my opinion, these are some of the necessary skills: UPDATE: I create a repo on github of hundreds of software links that should help get you started: https://github.com/josephmisiti/awesome-machine-learning 1. Python/C++/R/Java - you will probably want to learn all of these languages at some point if you want a job in machine-learning. Python's Numpy and Scipy libraries [2] are awesome because they have similar functionality to MATLAB, but can be easily integrated into a web service and also used in Hadoop (see below). C++ will be needed to speed code up. R [3] is great for statistics and plots, and Hadoop [4] is written in Java, so you may need to implement mappers and reducers in Java (although you could use a scripting language via Hadoop streaming [5]) 2. Probability and Statistics : A good portion of learning algorithms are based on this theory. Naive Bayes [6], Gaussian Mixture Models [7], Hidden Markov Models [8], to name a few. You need to have a firm understanding of Probability and Stats to understand these models. Go nuts and study measure theory [9]. Use statistics as an model evaluation metric: confusion matrices, receiver-operator curves, p-values, etc. 3. Applied Math + Algorithms : For discriminate models like SVMs [10], you need to have a firm understanding of algorithm theory. Even though you will probably never need to implement an SVM from scratch, it helps to understand how the algorithm works. You will need to understand subjects like convex optimization [11], gradient decent [12], quadratic programming [13], lagrange [14], partial differential equations [15], etc. Get used to looking at summations [16]. 4. Distributed Computing : Most machine learning jobs require working with large data sets these days (see Data Science) [17]. You cannot process this data on a single machine, you will have to distribute it across an entire cluster. Projects like Apache Hadoop [4] and cloud services like Amazon's EC2 [18] makes this very easy and cost-effective. Although Hadoop abstracts away a lot of the hard-core, distributed computing problems, you still need to have a firm understanding of map-reduce [22], distribute-file systems [19], etc. You will most likely want to check out Apache Mahout [20] and Apache Whirr [21]. 5. Expertise in Unix Tools : Unless you are very fortunate, you are going to need to modify the format of your data sets so they can be loaded into R,Hadoop,HBase [23],etc. You can use a scripting language like python (using re) to do this but the best approach is probably just master all of the awesome unix tools that were designed for this: cat [24], grep [25], find [26], awk [27], sed [28], sort [29], cut [30], tr [31], and many more. Since all of the processing will most likely be on linux-based machine (Hadoop doesnt run on Window I believe), you will have access to these tools. You should learn to love them and use them as much as possible. They certainly have made my life a lot easier. A great example can be found here [1]. 6. Become familiar with the Hadoop sub-projects : HBase, Zookeeper [32], Hive [33], Mahout, etc. These projects can help you store/access your data, and they scale. 7. Learn about advanced signal processing techniques : feature extraction is one of the most important parts of machine-learning. If your features suck, no matter which algorithm you choose, your going to see horrible performance. Depending on the type of problem you are trying to solve, you may be able to utilize really cool advance signal processing algorithms like: wavelets [42], shearlets [43], curvelets [44], contourlets [45], bandlets [46]. Learn about time-frequency analysis [47], and try to apply it to your problems. If you have not read about Fourier Analysis[48] and Convolution[49], you will need to learn about this stuff too. The ladder is signal processing 101 stuff though. Finally, practice and read as much as you can. In your free time, read papers like Google Map-Reduce [34], Google File System [35], Google Big Table [36], The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Data [37],etc There are great free machine learning books online and you should read those also. [38][39][40]. Here is an awesome course I found and re-posted on github [41]. Instead of using open source packages, code up your own, and compare the results. If you can code an SVM from scratch, you will understand the concept of support vectors, gamma, cost, hyperplanes, etc. It's easy to just load some data up and start training, the hard part is making sense of it all. Good luck. Machine learning has emerged as a revolutionary field that has brought advancements in various industries. Because of this, the demand for professionals with expertise in machine learning continues to grow. Here we’ve listed some of the possible career paths in Machine Learning. Machine Learning Engineer A Machine Learning Engineer runs various machine learning experiments using programming language such as Python, Java, Scala , etc. with the appropriate machine learning libraries. They also analyzes data to create various machine learning algorithms that run autonomously with minimal human super Continue Reading Machine learning has emerged as a revolutionary field that has brought advancements in various industries. Because of this, the demand for professionals with expertise in machine learning continues to grow. Here we’ve listed some of the possible career paths in Machine Learning. Machine Learning Engineer A Machine Learning Engineer runs various machine learning experiments using programming language such as Python, Java, Scala , etc. with the appropriate machine learning libraries. They also analyzes data to create various machine learning algorithms that run autonomously with minimal human supervision. Some of the essential skills required for this role are Programming, Probability, Statistics, Data Modeling, System Designing, Machine Learning Algorithms, etc. Data Scientist A Data Scientist uses advanced tools like Machine Learning and Predictive Modeling to gather, analyze, and understand lots of data. They find useful information from this data, which helps company executives make important business decisions. So, knowing Machine Learning is crucial for a Data Scientist, along with other skills like data mining and statistical research techniques. NLP (Natural Language Processing) Scientist An NLP Scientist is someone who works on making machines that can learn how people speak and translate spoken words into different languages. To do this, the NLP Scientist needs to be really good at the structure, spelling, and grammar of at least one language. They also need to know about machine learning so that they can teach the machine to do the same thing. Business Intelligence Developer A Business Intelligence Developer is someone who uses special tools like Data Analytics and Machine Learning to gather, analyze, and understand lots of data. They find useful insights from this data, which helps company executives make important business decisions. To do this job well, a Business Intelligence Developer needs to know about different types of databases like relational and multidimensional databases. They also need to be skilled in programming languages like SQL, Python, Scala, and Perl. Knowledge of business analytics services like Power BI would be really helpful! Human-Centered Machine Learning Designer A Human-Centered Machine Learning Designer develops machine learning systems that place users at the core of their design. They emphasize understanding user needs, creating user-friendly interfaces, and addressing ethical concerns. By prioritizing user experience and fairness, they ensure the resulting machine learning models and applications are valuable, accessible, and aligned with human requirements. Robotics Engineer Robotics Engineers design, build, and maintain robots for various purposes. They work on creating robots that can perform tasks efficiently, either by imitating human actions or optimizing processes. These professionals develop advanced computer vision systems to enable robots to interpret and interact with their surroundings accurately and safely. Additionally, they may design machine-learning algorithms to process extensive data generated by robots, enhancing their capabilities in tasks like assembly and automation. Artificial Intelligence (AI) Engineer An Artificial Intelligence Engineer specializes in developing and implementing AI systems and applications. They work on designing and training machine learning models, creating natural language processing algorithms, and building computer vision systems. These engineers solve complex problems, optimize algorithms, and enhance AI technologies to create intelligent software and systems that can perform tasks, make predictions, and learn from data autonomously. Software Developer Software Developer focuses on creating software applications and systems that incorporate machine learning capabilities. They design and implement algorithms, data processing pipelines, and model training procedures to enable the software to learn from data and make intelligent decisions or predictions. These developers work on optimizing machine learning models for performance and scalability, integrating them into existing software infrastructure, and continuously improving the learning capabilities of the applications they build. They collaborate with data scientists and other developers to deliver advanced and efficient machine learning-powered solutions for various industries and domains. Computational Linguist A Computational Linguist is a professional who combines expertise in linguistics and computer science to develop language-related technologies and natural language processing (NLP) systems. They work on understanding and analyzing human language using computational methods. Some of their key tasks include designing algorithms for language processing, developing speech recognition systems, building machine translation models, and working on text analysis and sentiment analysis. Computational Linguists play a crucial role in enhancing communication between humans and machines, enabling applications like virtual assistants, language translation software, and text analytics tools.
